[[Image:Coat of Arms of Syldavia.png|thumb|200px|right|The coat-of-arms of [[Syldavia]] features a motto in [[Syldavian]], which is based on Marols. It reads ''Eih bennek, eih blavek'', in [[English language|English]]: ("Here I am, here I stay").]]
For the popular Belgian [[comic]] series [[The Adventures of Tintin|Tintin]], the author [[HergÃ©]] modeled his fictional languages [[Syldavian]]<ref>[http://www.zompist.com/syldavian.html HergÃ©'s Syldavian<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> and [[Bordurian]] on Marols, and modeled many other personal and place-names in his works on the dialect (e.g. the city of KhemkhÃ¢h in the fictional [[Middle Eastern]] country of Khemed comes from the Marols phrase for "I'm cold"). Bordurian, for example, has as one of its words the Marols-based "mÃ¤nhir", meaning "mister" (cf. [[Flemish language|Flemish]] "mijnheer"). In the original French, the fictional Arumbaya language of [[San Theodoros]] is another incarnation of Marols.
